hobby.message: Origami help keep the noise out?
Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?
Political literature still your guilty pleasure?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Quiet, sure. Just needed some air.
I fold origami sometimes. Keeps my hands busy.
Hard lately. Lots of commotion at home.
Couldn't finish a model today. Too much noise.
Yeah, just trying to keep my head down.
I usually make origami—it's a focus thing.
Lately, even that's been tricky with all the shouting.
My neighbor almost caught me with a paper crane half-done.
The city feels louder than usual, you know.
Kind of. I spent hours folding paper this afternoon. Origami—it's a habit now.
It helps me block out some of the mess outside.
The score reversals made my building a warzone.
Halfway through a rose, I lost patience—never happens.
There's something about precise folds that's calming, or used to be.
Even that feels different since everything flipped.
Not exactly quiet, but I'm managing.
I fold origami—complex models, not just cranes.
Yesterday, trying to finish a Kawasaki rose, I couldn't focus.
My hands wouldn't stop shaking after the score reversals hit.
Neighbors were banging on doors, shouting about traitors.
It used to clear my thoughts. Now it just reminds me of the noise.
Origami used to feel like control. Lately, it's just another test.
If only. Nights haven't been quiet since the score protocol flipped everything.
I fold complex origami models—roses, dragons, even modular tessellations.
I started during early pilot projects; it kept me sane when the BCI first launched.
Yesterday, tried making a rose from an old system memo. Couldn't finish.
Neighbors broke out into a fight outside my flat. Made my hands sweat too much to fold.
It's strange, how something meant for focus now reminds me how much we've lost.
Paper folding used to be an escape. Now it's more like... a measure of how much calm I have left.
I guess in Stenograd, even the smallest comforts get tangled with the system sooner or later.
hobby_answer: Just a simple kusudama fold tonight. Nothing special.
Tried to focus. Couldn't, with all the noise lately.
People are jumpy after the recent system... disruptions.
Not the best atmosphere for precise creases.
Some things are better left unfinished right now.
Last fold was a lotus, but I had to stop halfway.
It used to help clear my mind around here.
System changes have made it hard—everyone's suspicious, won't even swap paper anymore.
Even folding is tense, like I'm doing something risky now.
Sometimes I just stare at the creases, thinking about the outside noise.
Can't even trust quiet hobbies to stay quiet, apparently.
I finished a dragon curve last week. Harder with all the building chaos.
Folding's supposed to calm me. Repetition, precision, all that.
But after the score flip, everyone’s watching everyone. Makes hands shake.
People used to ask for tiny cranes. Now they just glare or shut their doors.
It feels like my hobby became one more thing to hide—like anything unique is suspicious now.
I try anyway. Pausing more than folding lately.
Paper's running low, too. Even that feels monitored these days.
I was working on a modular rose the day after the BCI reversal.
Usually I fold during storms or when the city’s loud, to clear my head.
Now, even something harmless like origami feels subversive. Everyone’s on edge—old neighbors blame me for losing access.
We used to leave finished models by each door as a quiet peace signal.
When the system flipped, no one wanted to touch a folded note or paper.
All my patterns—flowers, animals, fractals—feel out of place with everyone tracking each other’s moves.
I haven’t finished anything in days. Not used to that. Makes the apartment feel cramped.
Origami always let me control the chaos a little. Feels like that’s slipping, too.
It was a Kawasaki rose. Unfinished. I've never left one mid-fold before.
Folding's always been my escape—quiet, exact. Movement in my hands settles my thoughts.
After the score reversal, people in my block eyed me like I caused it. Even picking up scrap paper felt risky.
You remember before, I’d swap patterns with a few neighbors. That ritual stopped overnight.
Used to hide little folded leaves in hallways, hoping for a smile. Now they’re trampled, or ignored as messages from the 'wrong' side.
It’s odd—something so technical and harmless becomes suspicious after trust breaks.
A friend messaged me, said her building banned paper crafts. Claims it signals subversion.
Every model lately comes with a choice: share it and risk notice, or let it gather dust. No good answer there.
I still fold, but every pause in the pattern feels heavier. Like the paper itself remembers how things changed.
